step.context: \text{Intuitively, where all could f(x) - as defined }\\ \text{above - be discontinuous?}
step.reason: \text{For }x\lt 1\text{ and }x\gt 1, f(x)\text{ is a straight line.}\\ \text{And straight lines are continuous.}\\ \text{However, there could be a discontinuity at } x=1\\ \text{where the two curves meet - or don't meet.}

\textbf{Be careful }\text{about which f(x) to use}\\ \text{when finding the left- and right-hand limits.}\\ \text{For a function to be continuous at a point}\\ \textbf{two conditions}\text{ must be satisfied}\\ \begin{tabular}{l|c} \hline \text{In English} & \text{Mathematically} \\ \hline \text{The function must approach} & \\ \text{the same value from the left } & \\ \text{and the right} & \lim_{x\to a}f(x)\text{ exists.}\\ \text{And that value should be} & \\ \text{equal to the value of the} & \\ \text{function at that point} & \lim_{x\to a}f(x) = f(a) \\ \hline \end{tabular}\\ \text{This also means that wherever a function is}\\ \text{continuous, it can be drawn without lifting}\\ \text{the pencil.}

choices.tex: \text{x=1 is the only point of continuity}
\text{f(x) is continuous everywhere in\\ it's domain}
\text{x=1 is the only point of discontinuity}
